title: The Everest 2019: Tommy Berry, Greg Hickman enjoying fairytale ride with Pierata
text:
Racing editor Ray Thomas and the team discuss the weekend's big races, including The Everest and Caulfield Cup.

They share a mutual respect and friendship that was forged in those days when both were dreamers.

When Greg Hickman was working two jobs, hoping for that big break as a trainer. When Tommy Berry was still in primary school, wishing the years away so he could become a jockey.

Nearly 20 years have passed. Dreams have come true. Ambitions have been realised. Their relationship has endured. But success hasn’t changed either man. Hickman recalled a moment just a few years ago which he said typified Berry’s work ethic and loyalty.

“Tommy has always been there for us,’’ Hickman said.

“I remember on the morning of the 2013 Golden Slipper, Tommy was going to ride favourite (and eventual winner Overreach) later that day but he still came to trackwork and jumped on some for me.

“There’s not too many kids who would do that for you when they are about to ride in the biggest race of their life.

“But that’s what Tommy’s like, he’s never changed from the days when he used to come to the track before school with his brother, Nathan, to be around the stables and horses. He has never forgotten his roots – his Mum and Dad make sure of that.’’

Berry also remembers that morning six years ago and, in particular, the promise he had made to Hickman earlier that week.

“I had told Greg I would be at trackwork that morning and felt it was important to be there for him,’’ Berry said. “Greg is always at the track early in the mornings, doing the hard yards, so there is no excuse for me.

“Only last Friday night, I was best man at my cousin’s wedding and I got home at 2am. My wife, Sharnee, said you better not go to trackwork that morning and I said I wouldn’t.

“But when Sharnee woke up, I wasn’t there. I had woken at 4am, got up and went to ride trackwork for Chris Waller.

“I’m not trying to impress anyone, but I don’t want to let anyone down. Trainers expect you to be there and very rarely, even if I’m sick, do I not turn up for trackwork.

“My job (Saturday) is to try and win an Everest so I need to be as fit as I can.

“I’m a routine person, anyway, I want to get to trackwork. It’s just the way I am and the way my parents brought me up.’’

Perhaps, it is destiny that the two men find themselves joining forces for what could be the biggest moment of their racing careers with Pierata in the $14 million The TAB Everest (1200m) at Royal Randwick on Saturday.

Pierata, who will come out of the inside barrier, is one of the early favourites for The Everest with TAB Fixed Odds listing him at $5.50 behind only Arcadia Queen at $4.20 and Santa Ana Lane at $4.60.

The Hickman-trained Pierata has been in spectacular form this spring, finishing a very close second to Redzel when resuming in the Concorde Stakes before powering past Classique Legend and Redzel to win The Shorts.

Hickman has given Pierata four weeks between runs to ensure he is fresh and ready for The Everest. The trainer’s preparation has been meticulously planned for the big race.

This has been like a second coming for Pierata as the outstanding five-year-old was going to be retired to stud after securing his Group 1 win in the All Aged Stakes back in April before the decision was made to put him back into work for another season, primarily to target The Everest.

Before the spring, Pierata had won seven of his 19 starts and more than $3 million prizemoney but Hickman is also convinced the five-year-old is an even better horse now.

“Pierata was always an immature colt and you can’t make something into what they are not,’’ Hickman said.

“But this horse has done a super job to do what he has done, winning those races in Queensland as a three-year-old including the Magic Millions Guineas was a tremendous effort when he was so immature.

“He developed again as a four-year-old although he was still nowhere near the finished article. He weighed 480kg when he won the All Aged in the autumn and he was 526kg when I weighed him earlier this week.

“That’s the difference in him now, he’s bigger and stronger but he’s still a lovely horse to deal with, he’s got a great attitude.’’

Pierata comes from a sire lineage of champions from Octagonal to Lonhro and Pierro.

Those three were champion racehorses and each shared another common trait – a remarkably relaxed demeanour.

Hickman saw plenty of Lonhro and particularly Octagonal when he used to work at Crown Lodge for Hall of Fame trainer John Hawkes, and said Pierata shares a very similar disposition to those great horses.

“Pierata is very calm and professional, he’s a marvellous horse to work with,’’ Hickman said.

“There was one morning at trackwork I was out with Darren Beadman and even he said Pierata looks like Lonhro which was a pretty good compliment for my horse.’’

Berry agreed Pierata has returned a superior racehorse this spring.

“Pierata feels like a different horse this preparation,’’ Berry said. “His action is a lot cleaner, he strides out a lot better, he’s bigger and stronger, he’s matured into a really nice horse.

“He used to get a bit agitated in the mounting yard and behind the barriers but he now takes everything in his stride.

“I’m glad they made the decision to bring him back for one more season. It would have been a shame if he went to stud with his best racing still ahead of him.’’

Berry said if Pierata can win the richest race on turf, it would be one of the more satisfying moments of his celebrated career.

“It would mean a great deal to me to win it for Greg,’’ he said.

“He is someone I’ve grown up with and I’ve seen him go through some great times and some really tough times. He’s had his ups and downs.

“A lot of Pierata’s owners have been with Greg for many years and they are a terrific bunch of people. I’ve been riding for them since I was 34kg!

“I know Greg has done everything possible to have Pierata right for the day. Greg will turn this horse out in superb order for The Everest.’’

Despite the extraordinary hype leading into The Everest, Hickman has also kept everything in perspective.

“The horse and jockey will give it everything and if we can get a bit of luck in running, then we won’t be far away,’’ Hickman said.

“If we win, that would be incredible. I don’t think it will change my life but it would make things a lot easier, monetary-wise.

“The way I look at it, a lot of people in racing devote their lives to this sport and don’t get a horse as good as this.

“I have had some nice horses in my stable over the years but Pierata has been the best. I’ve been very lucky. As a mate of mine said the just the other day, I started off broke and I’m just trying to improve on it.’’
description: They share a mutual respect and friendship that was forged in those days when both were dreamers.
